Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: flank; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope; Snowmobile tracks on slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes:
Stable snowpack observed at this location. The remains of several slab avalanches are observed on eastern slopes, but they are all at least a week old or even from January. Slopes with a western aspect seem quite windblown and are not well covered.
The separate layers from each snowfall and wind event have bonded very well together and are of a very similar hardness, making it very hard for me to distinguish them. There may be some more "hidden" layers in the snowpack besides those noted, but the bonding there is even better and they are likely not of any significance. The entire column is removed after the test using a shovel, and it refuses to break further, even after moving it around, carrying it, letting it fall to the side, etc.
Two compression test were performed and the results were the same for CT26. On the second test, I really slammed the column excessively and thus produced a break in the column at 180 cm at CT30. Continuing to hit the column excessively after 30 for several more hits resulted in a break and smooth slide, Q2, at 100 cm.
Given the forecast, the avalanche danger will likely remain low over the next few days.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Red flags: One small dry loose slough-like slide on a 35-40 degree slope that entrained the 3 or 4 inches of surface snow, about 2 feet wide and ran for 10 feet. As I skied down a 35-40 degree slope there was some sloughing of the dry sugary surface snow, as well.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Test profile in small opening in trees in lee side of ridge. Smooth ground.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized;
Pit is adjacent to avalanche: flank;
Collapsing, localized; Ski tracks on slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: We skied just out of bounds of Mt. Rose ski area into the Davis Creek drainage. There were dozens of ski tracks in the Davis Creek area with no signs of release or instability. Wind scouring was noticed on ridges but plentiful snow was found in more protected areas. Buried surface hoar that was knocked down in a prior wind event was observed roughly 20cm deep, although difficult to identify. CTN was observed on this layer in some of our tests, but not in others. Surface faceting was prevalent in the upper 10cm of the snowpack.
The surface hoar layer is not pronounced and grains showed some rounding. Cracks formed along the new snow layer interfaces during the ECT, but none propagated beyond the width of the shovel.
Crown profile investigating reported Sa 2023-01-29 on Nak. Average 70cm crown. Propagated across 2 steep open gullies at TL.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope;
Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; Pit is adjacent to avalanche: flank; Recent avalanche activity on different slopes; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes:
Dug 150 CM Pit; Total Snow Pack was approx 195-200 CM
Adjacent avalanche (SS-N-D2-O/S) ran for approx 100 yards (estimated). Appears to be fresh from previous day’s heavy snowfall. Guessing it failed on Old Snow surface approx 20-30 cm down. Slide path was on substantially steeper terrain then test area.
Mycket lätt marknära snödrev till och från. Brottkantprofil i drevsnöflak som visar tydlig sprickutbredning.
Liten testsluttning

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Depth hoar showing signs of sintering.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry;

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: pit on loaded NW aspect of Blueberry Knoll

Pit_Observation.activities: Cracking; Snowmobile tracks on slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Cold temperatures (around 17 degrees) that fell quickly while I dug the pit with a passing cold front. Sky started as cloudy, then broken clouds with a moment or two of sun, then foggy with some flurries. Trees in area were lightly rimed with little accumulated snow on them, knocked off from earlier wind. Trees further down slope had accumulated snow on them.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Skier triggered avalanche 1/30/2023. No one caught or injured. Occurred in the "Moonlight" run, just north of Fig Ridge (side country area to the north of Pebble Cr. Ski Area.) Started in two separated locations and joined. Crown face: 46 cm. Soft Slab. Slab composed of all new snow from the last couple of days. Ran 1,000 feet. Snapped off branches and small trees.
